awd_titl_txt: CS for All 2021 Researcher-Practitioner Partnership Development Workshops
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a broad and sustained effort underway for incorporating computer science and computational thinking into K-12 learning experiences. There are different models for helping teachers, school leaders, and researchers plan and implement innovations for computer science education. Researcher-practitioner partnerships (RPPs) bring teams from schools, districts, and/or state education agencies together with research organizations (e.g., universities or non-profits) to design and investigate teaching and learning. These partnerships are particularly important for creating learning experiences that broaden participation in computer science. The set of workshops in this project support the creation of RPPs for computer science education projects. Teams participate in the workshop and work with a partnership coach to help them with their computer science teaching and learning innovations. The virtual and in-person workshops provide information about how to organize and implement an RPP. 

The set of workshops focuses on expanding the community of researchers and education leaders who are developing RPPs for computer science education. Two workshops will be held (one virtual, one in-person) to bring together teams. Experts on RPPs serve as partnership coaches to provide tailored support for teams, providing information about how to design resources, collaborate, and conduct research about the changes in computer science teaching and learning that are planned to take place on each project. The workshop also provides information about the CS for All program and guidance about submitting proposals to this program at the National Science Foundation. Finally, the workshop offers evaluation expertise to support teams in crafting ways to collect data during their project to inform project goals.

This project is funded through the CS for All: Research and RPPs program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

Rice University, as the institutional home of the National Network of Education Research-Practice Partnerships (NNERPP), led a workshop in the fall of 2021 (virtual) to engage participants interested in learning how to form and sustain a research-practice partnership (RPP) capable of advancing the research, development, and implementation related goals associated with supporting K-12 Computer Science for All (CS for All). This workshop aimed to build the capacity of RPP teams interested in applying to the National Science Foundation's CS for All program to design effective RPP projects and proposals.

A second set of workshops was also offered during the spring 2022 PI meeting that took place in Philadelphia, PA to support existing RPP teams in reflecting together on their data needs for RPP continuous improvement, with a second workshop for RPP evaluators and practice-side team members to support their specific roles in the RPP continuous improvement process. 

Intellectual Merit:

All three workshops aimed to advance participants' understanding of the strategies, goals, and activities necessary to support the formation, development, and sustainability of research-practice partnerships (RPPs) oriented to support equity-centered initiatives and improvement efforts in Computer Science education, building on NNERPP's experience in facilitating three prior RPP workshops for the NSF CS for All program. 

In service of this aim, the fall 2021 workshop introduced attendees to a three-part RPP initiation framework that covered a number of critical elements to be considered when launching an RPP. These included RPP Design, which invited participants to reflect on questions related to the central problem of practice the partnership proposed to address; RPP Research, which invites teams to identify the research questions to be addressed (based closely on the problem of practice), the data infrastructure needed to support the studying of those questions, and the project management systems teams should consider implementing; and RPP Evaluation, which introduced participants to the Henrick, et al. (2017) five dimensions of RPP effectiveness framework and invited them to consider how it would guide their partnership processes. 

With respect to the two workshops that took place in the spring of 2022, both efforts aimed to provide critical opportunities for existing teams to reflect on their partnership efforts in support of continuous improvement (CI). For the first workshop focused on data needs, teams were invited to identify the types of data they might need to inform CI efforts, in addition to sharing strategies and practices that have served these purposes with other RPP teams. For the second workshop focused on RPP evaluators and practice-side members of the team, participants were invited to reflect on different ways of representing formative feedback reports in service of supporting CI efforts.

All workshops were designed, organized, and led by NNERPP in partnership with RPP experts from across the country.

Broader Impacts:

Through these workshops, participants were exposed to a new way of approaching research, implementation, and design in supporting equity-centered practitioner-focused initiatives in K-12 Computer Science education, i.e., through research-practice partnerships (RPPs). RPPs have the potential to provide the infrastructure to reimagine the roles of education researchers and practitioners as one where collaborative work meaningfully integrates diverse forms of expertise to tackle longstanding systemic problems that cannot be resolved in siloed ecosystems. These workshops invited participants to learn about the possibility of partnerships and support the initial formation of partnership projects or proposals for the Computer Science for All initiative, in addition to providing reflection opportunities in service of continuous improvement for existing RPP teams. 


Last Modified: 12/27/2022
Modified by: Maria P Arce-Trigatti
